newsitem.title: USA: Norwood says Alpha unit hurts EPS.
newsitem.headline: Norwood says Alpha unit hurts EPS.

text.p: Norwood Promotional Products Inc said Thursday its Alpha unit is hurting its earnings per share, and it is therefore exploring alternatives for the unit.
The company said it believe the steps it will take with respect to Alpha will have a net positive impact on its results in fiscal 1998 and beyond.
The company did not provide information on what these steps are.
The company said Alpha's core promotional products business has exceeded sales and profitability targets, but sales of its non-promotional, or retail, operation have lagged.
The company said earnings per share for the 1997 third quarter would have been $0.62 if results of the Alpha division were excluded. The company's actual earnings per share were $0.52.
The company said it believes Alpha will cost it $0.30 to $0.35 in earnings per share for fiscal 1997 as a whole.
The company said Alpha's non-promotional product sales are typically characterized by large orders for direct premium markets and convenience stores.
These sales, the company said, have a "much greater" degree of unpredictability than its other businesses.
The company said, therefore, it must begin exploring alternatives regarding the Alpha division. It said it has instituted a process to do so in the next 45 days.
The company also said it has signed a letter with Merrill Lynch for a new senior secured credit facility of $125 million, which replaces its existing facility of $60 million.
